title: Financial Transparency
description: Explore how open you want to be about money with each other.

questions.text: When it comes to knowing what my partner earns, I feel...
choices: I'd want to know early on - it's practical info
I'd want to know eventually, but no rush
It's private unless we're combining finances
It doesn't really matter to me

therapeutic.rationale: Attitudes about income transparency vary widely based on upbringing, culture, and past experiences. Some see it as basic practical info; others as deeply private. Neither is wrong, but assumptions cause friction.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one wants to know and one values privacy, don't push—but do name the difference. Ask: 'What makes this feel private for you?' Understanding the why matters more than the number.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared transparency comfort makes this easy. If you both want to know, share when it feels right. If you both prefer privacy, respect that—but revisit as your partnership deepens.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How did your family handle talking about income? Was it open or secret? How does that shape your view now?

questions.text: When it comes to debt, my view is...
choices: Being debt-free should be a priority
Some debt is fine if it's manageable
Debt is a tool - it depends on what it's for
I try not to stress about it

therapeutic.rationale: Attitudes toward debt are deeply personal and often rooted in upbringing. Some see any debt as failure; others see it as strategic. These beliefs shape major life decisions—education, homes, lifestyle.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different debt philosophies can clash when making big decisions. The debt-averse partner may feel anxious about a mortgage; the debt-tolerant partner may feel held back. Understand the belief beneath the position.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared debt philosophy makes big decisions easier. But stay curious—views can shift with life circumstances.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What did your family believe about debt? How has that shaped your own view?

questions.text: For everyday spending, I think we should...
choices: Each do our own thing, no need to share
Mention bigger purchases but not everything
Be pretty open about what we're spending on
Know exactly where the money goes

therapeutic.rationale: Day-to-day spending visibility preferences reflect comfort with structure vs. autonomy. Some find tracking reassuring; others find it controlling. This shapes what 'normal' financial life feels like.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The tracker may feel anxious without visibility; the autonomous spender may feel monitored. Find a middle ground—maybe shared visibility for joint expenses, freedom for personal spending.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched preferences make daily money life smooth. Two trackers can nerd out on budgets together. Two autonomous spenders just need to ensure the big picture stays healthy.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How would you feel if your partner wanted to see all your purchases? How about if they never asked?

questions.text: When I'm stressed about money, I tend to...
choices: Talk about it right away
Process it alone first, then share
Keep it to myself unless it's serious
Avoid thinking about it

therapeutic.rationale: How we process financial stress mirrors broader stress patterns. External processors need to talk; internal processors need space first. Neither is hiding—they're coping differently.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The talker may feel shut out by the processor's silence; the processor may feel pressured by the talker's urgency. Ask: 'Do you need space or company right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Two talkers can spiral together—watch for that. Two processors may both suffer in silence. Create a ritual for surfacing money stress before it builds.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When money stress hits, what's your first instinct? Does your partner know what helps you?

questions.text: The level of financial openness I want in a relationship is...
choices: Full transparency - no money secrets
Mostly open with room for some privacy
Open about shared stuff, private about personal
Each person manages their own, we share what's needed

therapeutic.rationale: Your ideal transparency level reflects deep values about partnership, autonomy, and trust. Some couples merge everything; others maintain strong financial independence. What matters is alignment, not a 'right' answer.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different ideals need negotiation. The full-transparency person may feel the private person is hiding something; the private person may feel controlled. Find where you both feel trusted AND trusting.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared transparency ideals make money life easier to design. Build systems that match your shared vision.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does trust around money look like to you? What would break it?
